reviewText: Oh yes this is great. Is it bad? Obviously. Is it great at the same time? Absoluetly. From the constant playing of the theme song (twice within the first 10 minutes!) to the Group of people clearly on variying drugs "moshing" to ballad songs to the killer suffocating a Girl with a giant bag of weed - this is excellent. Give it a watch. Give it many watches. Show it to your friends. Don't ignore this. I suggest not or EVIL may come for you.

reviewText: Succinctly, bad acting by bad actors, given bad script containing bad dialogue. Watch for one of my favorite scenes (cynically) in horror movie history in which a policeman looking in I believe a parking garage recites with great depth and emotion what amounts to  perhaps the only line he ever read in his acting career, "Look, more blood." It was a line my friends and I used tongue in cheek for a variety of reasons for quite some time (eg. @ a baseball game, "Look, more Bud"). But that typifies the pitiful quality of all things involved in this flick. Roz Kelly was supposed to be the  draw in this piece of dreck, but the fact she can't act only adds to the terrible plot, plausibility and drama involved in what became one of many horror movies based on a certain holiday. I'm sure I've seen this rated among the worst horror movies, much less movies in general by several sources. Watch this if you want to see why. For the record, I saw this when we'd go see any horror movie when drunk enough not to care what it was.
summary: Sorry. Zero stars was not available.
Title: N/A

reviewText: NEW YEAR'S EVIL is another forgotten slasher from the late 70s / early 80s. As w/ MANIAC, THE PROWLER, etc., NYE is due for a revival. A popular DJ (Roz Kelly) is hosting a big, televised NEW YEAR'S EVIL (yep, that's what she calls it!) bash. Meanwhile, a non-mask-wearing, verbal killer (Kip Niven) is planning on murdering a different victim in each US time zone, at the stroke of midnight! He calls Kelly's character, and lets her hear a recording of his first victim's death, and the game is on. While not the best movie of its type, it does get points for deviating a bit from the old, tired "stalk 'n' slash" formula. Worth including in your next holiday-themed horror marathon...

reviewText: I am a jaded movie fan with a soft spot for the 80's.  There's something about the 80's with it's polarizing "we're the good guys" and "communism is evil" that I just can't enough of.  For a movie to get an R it had to show some nudity or fairly disturbing violence instead of today where a movie can get a R for dropping one F-bomb.I had never heard of this movie, and figured it was just another lame holiday slasher.  I was wrong.  I was very wrong.The price is a bit much, but it's definitely worth.  Highly recommended.
summary: The definition of an 80's slasher hidden gem
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you enjoyed this review, make sure to check out my horror blog at: brandoncsites.blogspot.comNew Year's Evil (1980) * / 4D: Emmett AlstonC: Roz Kelly, Kip Niven, Chris Wallace, Grant Cramer, Louisa Moritz, Jed MillsP: A serial killer murders a new victim each hour as the clock strikes Midnight in various time zones on New Year's Eve with a TV host intended as his final victim.In my opinion, a modern day anti-hero needs a certain level of charisma or something about them that makes them stand out and causes audiences to take note of them. Some great modern day anti-heroes include Freddy Krueger in A Nightmare on Elm Street, Jason Voorhees in the Friday the 13th series or Pinhead in Hellraiser.The anti-hero of New Year's Evil is a gravely voiced serial killer whose modus operandi, in part, is that he kills based on when the clock strikes Midnight in various time zones. He's greater purpose is revealed in a twist ending. There's nothing about the way that he talks that makes him come across as charismatic. In fact, his voice is quite off putting. He doesn't have any kind of swagger. He doesn't have any kind of charm. And when his ultimate motive is revealed, as it turns out, he's just another ordinary serial killer.There's nothing particularly innovative about the carnage that the killer of New Year's Evil engages in. In fact, the carnage that he engages in is grisly and tough to stomach. A large part of the film is told from the killer's point of view. He kills, but we don't know why and that is the central mystery behind New Year's Evil. The possibilities were endless. There were so many different things they could have done with this material. The writers could have let their imagination run wild with this one, but at the end of the day, what we're given is just another slasher film with just another mad killer running amok. [R] 90 mins.
Title: N/A

reviewText: New Year's Evil is an early 80's slasher movie that isn't like most of its type. The killer in this one doesn't wear a mask (at least not most of the time), and he talks. I prefer my slashers to be masked and silent, but that's just me. This one isn't bad, and does have some effective moments of suspense. However, if it's gore and T & A that you want, this one doesn't deliver much of either. There are some beautiful women in this, including Roz Kelly who gives a good performance. And the ending is great. I clapped when I saw who was behind the wheel of that ambulance. Very creepy. Too bad the rest of the movie wasn't that great.

reviewText: It's very interesting how all these horror movies that have been on fan demand lists for DVD releases are getting released on DVD-Rs instead of actual manufactured DVDs. CLEARLY there's a demand for them, so why are the movie companies totally skimping and cheating the customers of quality releases while charging full price? Sure, New Year's Evil's film quality actually looks really good. I expected a bad VHS transfer, but the quality is great for such an old film. So it's tragic that it's recorded on a purple disc. Sorry, but I've burned plenty of my own purple DVDs, and not only do they usually play in very limited machines, but after a few plays, they get these odd rings on the actual information surface of the disc and become completely unreadable. Is that what I have to look forward to with my copy of New Year's Evil?Hey. if these companies don't think it's worth their money to give us full-fledged DVD releases of these films, why not just do a little compression on four of the films, slap two on each side of a double disc, and charge us 20 bux for an ACTUAL DVD release? I'd much prefer that over a disc I could make myself if I recorded these movies off cable...
summary: OK, I'll say it--yet another DVD-R release at real DVD prices...

reviewText: First of all, I am a fan of 80s horror film, and so the cheesier the better. This movie is pretty good if you like slasher films, but there is very little blood to be found in this film. The worst part is that you don't get to see the killings at all except for a woman who is asphyxiated with a plastic dope bag. I take that back, the worst is that you want Blaze, the main character the killer is after, to die. She is nothing more than a self centered person who doesn't even acknowledge her son and you kinda hope she gets it in the end.So, overallNot much bloodNot much nudityMain character that you hope will dieWith all of that, it is still not the worst film I have seen.

reviewText: [good things]The movie delivers a pretty nice twist at the end (well, close to the end) where the killer, who was pretty much known from minute one, reveals his motives. The lead up to the point confused the hell out of me. I think that sequence was really carried out and executed pretty slickly. There was another "suspect" introduced in the film, which again was really confusing until the very end. All in all, the movie not being very good, these parts helped out a lot. The movie also had the 1980's new wave cheese feel to it.[the bad]The movie didn't really provide much blood, creative kills, nudity, or edge-of-seat action suspense. The movie really had nothing redeeming about it except for the killer's motive.[final thoughts]I don't know... I am really hung up on this movie. I didn't fully get into it, or even enjoy it. I did think the writing was pretty good, and enjoyed the twist. The movie was merely a resemblance of a made for T.V. Lifetime movie. It really had no scares, or anything that made the slasher films of this era work. It seems one of two things; thrown together really fast, and without much thought or severely cut to pieces. Regardless, I don't think anything would have made this movie action-packed or exciting. If you are like me, and pride yourself on watching any 1980's slasher you can get your hands on, watch it. Just don't expect a masterpiece.
summary: Not as good as Christmas Evil

reviewText: What do you get when you have a lame story, an idiotic supporting cast, a killer who is about as scary as the Easter Bunny and your biggest star is Pinky Tuscadero? A movie that Comcast's Fear Net shows for free because no one with their brain screwed on tight would pay to watch it. The entire story was so abysmal because there wasn't any character that could be identified with. Not the killer, not the heroine, no one. The ending included a slight twist. However it would have been a lot better if that annoying old redhead came crashing down with the elevator. If you like horrible '80s slashers that are so implausible that they're laughable then this may be for you.

reviewText: For a description of the plot, etc., read other reviews.  Just some quick thoughts on this "unsafe holiday" slasher...New Year's Evil (1980) is one of the "no holiday is safe anymore" slashers that were being manufactured in the early 1980s.  First we had the holiday movie that started it all - Black Christmas (1974), then Halloween, Friday The 13th, Happy Birthday To Me, My Bloody Valentine, April Fools Day, Prom Night, Silent Night Deadly Night, Christmas Evil, and on and on and on.  New Year's Evil is a pretty decent low budget slasher that has a creepy killer.  The acting is mediocre to below average.  It isn't a bad flick, but it isn't great, either.  It's entertaining enough to see at least once.If you're in the mood for one of the countless holiday slashers, then give this one a try.

reviewText: This is a flick that I watch every new years and probably have since I saw it originally in 1982.  It's a typical slasher flick from the 80's and was one of the earlier ones.The plot is pretty simple, a killer is going around and killing people at each midnight in each timezone and he calls himself Evil.  He calls into a punk countdown show and plays the cassettes (yes it was the 80's) back so that everyone can hear the killings.  His primary target seems to be the host of the show.I won't give anymore away but you find out who the killer is pretty early on.  There is not a lot of suspense but the special effects are decent for a slasher.  This is nothing exceptional but it is kind of a tradition to watch this every year so that's why I gave it 4 stars.  I was surprised by the quality of the film, I figured it would be a rough "videotape" dub but it really was a clean copy of the film so it made it a pleasure to view as my old videotape edition is definitely seeing a lot of wear and tear.If your into the 80's slasher films then this is one that you definitely should view.  If you want the newer flashier and gorier (CGI) movies this one will probably not please you too much.

reviewText: New Years Evil is an early entry in the slasher movie boom.  Coming out hot on the heels of Friday the 13th, it's an obvious attempt at the "holiday" slasher movie theme.  However, this movie doesn't take the Jason/Michael/Madman Marz approach of making the killer an almost supernatural, unstoppable juggernaut who never speaks.  This is more of the When A Stranger Calls style, where the killer is a more true to life psychopath.  No mask, no mystery.  We see him constantly and half of the film is devoted to following him around as he goes on his spree.  Basically he's the central character of the film.  Throughout the film, "Richard" AKA "Evil" calls into a televised rock and roll New Years Eve extravaganza hosted by Rozz Kelly.  His plan is to commit four murders, one for each time zone(New York on through to California) when the clock strikes midnight for the New Year.  Th final murder is to be Rozz herself.  Dear God, who is this guy??  Well, those fluent in horror films will figure out what's really happening long before the movie ends.Not much in the gore or suspense departments, but the performance of Kip Niven as the sly psychopath is actually quite good.But being that there are no surprises here, this movie will still be entertaining for fans of slasher films and classic(and I use the term lightly here)horror films.  Fans of Resident Evil: 4-DArmegeddonwastelandplaguematrixripoff will simply hate it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One star?!!  Obviously, somebody doesn't appreciate low budget horror!  New Year's Evil is one of the better "slasher" films of the 80s, in my opinion.  I'm sure many would disagree with me, but N.Y.E. is way more interesting than the extremely overrated Friday The 13th Pt. 1, a movie so boring that I've only watched it once.  I just saw N.Y.E. last week and I've already watched it twice, I'm pretty sure I'm gonna make my friends watch it on New Year's Eve too!  N.Y.E. isn't overly gory and it's easy to figure out who the killer is, but this movie has that charm that only 70s and 80s low budget horror films can contain.  If you love ignored horror gems like Sleepaway Camp, Night Of The Creep or Rock 'N Roll Nightmare then definitely give New Year's Evil a view.
summary: Very good watch for the true horror hounds!
